subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, July 2020

title: Decoding Hate podcast
subtitle: SAIFE Spotlight Initiative, Katie Pentney, February 2021
description:
A six-episode series that explores the connection between freedom of expression, artificial intelligence, and hate speech online. Human rights lawyer Katie Pentney discusses with leading experts what freedom of expression means in the digital age, the challenges of combating online hate speech, and the complexities of content moderation. 

Featuring discussions with: Nani Jansen Reventlow; Deniz Wagner; Tarlach McGonagle; Jillian York; Thiago Dias Oliva; Sahana Udupa; Molly Land; and Rikke Frank Jørgensen

subtitle: SAIFE Spotlight Initiative, Susie Alegre, January-March 2021
description:
Human rights lawyer Susie Alegre joins the Better Human—a popular podcast hosted by UK barrister Adam Wagner—to lead a series of episodes that delve into an overlooked aspect of freedom of expression in the context of AI: freedom of opinion and freedom of information. Alegre invites experts from around the world to discuss the right to receive information and the ways in which AI affects what information we see and share. 

Featuring interviews with: Meetali Jain, Legal Director of Avaaz; Dr. Emma L. Briant, Maven of Persuasion; Professor Lorna Woods, University of Essex; Dr. Elif Mendos Kuskonmaz, University of Portsmouth; Brendan de Caires, Director of PEN Canada; and Professor Evelyn Aswad, University of Oklahoma.

They were asked about their use of AI, their awareness of the fundamental rights issues involved, and best practices for assessing and mitigating risks linked to the use of AI.

Drawing from Ranking Digital Rights’ extensive research on corporate policies and digital rights, the report examines how content curation and content moderation algorithms are used to propagate and prohibit different forms of online speech, and how this can cause or catalyze social harm, particularly in the context of the 2020 U.S. election.

title: Getting to the Source of Infodemics: It’s the Business Model
subtitle: Nathalie Maréchal, Rebecca MacKinnon, and Jessica Dheere, Ranking Digital Rights, May 2020
description: A report addressing the root cause of the proliferation of harmful content online: the surveillance-based business model. Authors make the case for policy solutions that address the systemic causes of today’s “infodemic”—with measures that include corporate governance reform and strong data protection rules—rather than solutions that require intermediaries to police and remove harmful materials, which can result in undue restrictions to online speech and access to information online.

title: The Manila Principles

subtitle: Danish Institute for Human Rights, November 2020

In particular, the workshop explored what international organizations such as the OSCE can and should be doing to better to support journalists and hold states to their commitments on safety of journalists, pluralism and media freedom.

During the session, preliminary research and workshop outcomes on this were presented and key findings discussed to provide concrete recommendations on protecting freedom of expression and other human rights in the use of AI for content governance in times of crises.

title: OECD Recommendation of the Council on Artificial Intelligence
subtitle: OECD Legal Instruments, May 2019
description: The Recommendation on Artificial Intelligence is the first intergovernmental standard on AI, and was adopted by the OECD Council. Its aim is to foster innovation and trust in AI, while ensuring respect for human rights and democratic values. It was revised in 2023 and 2024 to reflect technological and policy developments, including with respect to generative AI, and to further facilitate the recommendations' implementation.

title: UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence
subtitle: UNESCO, November 2021
description: Adopted in 2021 by 193 UNESCO Member States, this is the first global framework on AI ethics. The UNESCO Recommendation aims at approaching AI ethics as a systematic normative reflection based on a holistic, comprehensive, multicultural and evolving framework of interdependent values, principles and actions that can guide societies in dealing responsibly with known and unknown impacts of AI technologies on human beings, societies and the environment.

title: Fostering Media Freedom Literacy across the OSCE region report
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, May 2024
description: This report forms part of a project designed to support policy-making processes, cross-sectoral collaboration and public awareness of media literacy in the OSCE participating States. Exploring and explaining the concept of media freedom literacy and the competencies and skills it encompasses, this report aims at providing a practical tool to help advance media freedom literacy across the OSCE region.

title: Under the Watchful Eye: Human Rights, Gender and Surveillance
subtitle: Office of the Representative on Freedom of the Media, Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, Office of the High Commissioner on National Minorities, and the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly, supported by the OSCE Chaipersonship of Malta, March 2024
description: This event was jointly organized by OSCE Institutions supported by the Chairpersonship of Malta to mark International Women's Day 2024. The conference examines the intersection of gender and digital surveillance. In bringing together the three dimensions of the OSCE, it explores the gendered aspects of the surveillance landscape within the broader context of comprehensive security.

title: Under the Watchful Eye: Human Rights, Gender and Surveillance, Event Report
subtitle: Office of the Representative on Freedom of the Media, Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, Office of the High Commissioner on National Minorities, and the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly, supported by the OSCE Chaipersonship of Malta, March 2025
description: This outcome report follows the conference jointly organized by OSCE Institutions in March 2024 to mark International Women's Day 2024. It examines how surveillance technologies, whether deployed by State or private actors, often reinforce existing power imbalances and can perpetuate both gender-based discrimination and violence online and offline. In addition, the report discusses ways in which the human rights framework and digital technologies can be leverage to enhance human rights of women and girls, with a particular focus on minority women and female journalists in the OSCE region.

subtitle: Forum on Information and Democracy, February 2024

It presents recommendations addressed to States and AI companies, entities, and platforms aiming at ensuring a safe and responsible development and deployment of AI systems, establish appropriate liability and accountability regimes, and put in place governance and oversight mechanisms.

title: AI Act
subtitle: European Union, August 2024
description: The AI Act is part of the European Union's digital strategy and aims at regulating AI to ensure better conditions for the development and use of this new technology. This is the first European regulatory framework for AI, and it analyses and classifies different AI systems according to the risk they pose to users.

title: UNESCO Report Artificial Intelligence and Democracy
subtitle: UNESCO, May 2024
description: This report builds on the "Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence", delving into the current and potential impact of AI on democracy and the benefits that both AI and digitalization could bring to enhancing collective decision-making processes.

title: Media Freedom, Democracy and Security
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, July 2024
description: As part of the OSCE project "No Security Without Media Freedom: FoM Dialogues", this report analyses the nexus between security, democracy and media freedom. Based on scientific evidence, it showcases that democracy improves domestic and international security, and how independent media is one mechanism through which it does so.

title: Bucharest Declaration and Resolutions adopted by the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly at the 31st Annual Session - Resolution on AI and the fight against terrorism
subtitle: OSCE Parliamentary Assembly, July 2024
description: This resolution adopted by the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly stresses the impact of AI on various aspects of society, including international peace and security, and how it can be used to spread misinformation and conspiracy theories and lead to violent extremism and terrorism. The resolution encourages OSCE participating States to enact or strengthen existing legislation in order to prevent the misuse of AI by terrorists and violent extremists while ensuring the respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms, privacy rights and data protection standards in line with United Nations and EU standards.

title: Workshop on Big Tech and Media Freedom, Outcome Report
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, October 2024

Participants examined the role of Big Tech platforms which monopolize internet search services, social media, and digital advertising. This report explores the impact of Big Tech and emerging technologies on media dependencies and how these undermine democracy. title: Eternal You - AI, digital immortality, and information integrity
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, September 2024

The screening was followed by a panel discussion on the rise of AI-driven impersonation and how these technologies blur the lines between reality and hallucination, between fact and fiction, as well as their legal, human rights and ethical implications. This one pager summarises the main take-aways of the panel discussion.

title: Digital Services Act
subtitle: European Union, November 2022
description: The DSA is an EU regulation adopted in 2022 aiming at "contributing to the proper functioning of the internal market for intermediary services by setting out harmonised rules for a safe, predictable and trusted online environment that facilitates innovation and in which fundamental rights [...] are effectively protected" (Art.1). Its main goal is to prevent illegal and harmful activities online and the spread of disinformation. It ensures user safety, protects fundamental rights, and creates a fair and open online platform environment.

title: Framework Convention on Artificial Intelligence and Human Rights, Democracy and the Rule of Law
subtitle: Council of Europe, May 2024
description: This Framework Convention is the first international legally binding instrument in the field of AI, human rights, democracy and the rule of law. It aims to ensure that activities within the lifecycle of artificial intelligence systems are fully consistent with human rights, democracy and the rule of law, while being conducive to technological progress and innovation. This Framework Convention also aims to fill any legal gaps that may result from rapid technological advances.

title: Recommendation CM/Rec (2022)4 of the Committee of Ministers to member States on promoting a favourable environment for quality journalism in the digital age
subtitle: Council of Europe, March 2022
description: The recommendation presents guidelines to Council of Europe member States on promoting quality journalism in the digital age. It recalls the importance of quality journalism in all sectors of society, for strong and stable democracies, and how the rapid technological development has profoundly disrupted the news business in general and resulted in a rise of new challenges for quality journalism. The guidelines are designed to stimulate and reinforce independent, accurate and reliable quality journalism, committed to the pursuit of truth and to the need to minimise harm, as a pillar for the functioning of democracies.

title: Recommendation CM/Rec (2022)13 of the Committee of Ministers to member States on the impacts of digital technologies on freedom of expression
subtitle: Council of Europe, April 2022
description: Following the Recommendation CM/Rec (2022)4 on quality journalism in the digital age, this document presents guidelines to assist States, public and private actors, in particular internet intermediaries, as well as the media, civil society organisations, researchers and other relevant actors in their independent and collaborative efforts to protect and promote freedom of expression in the digital age. Aim of these guidelines is to ensure that digital technologies serve rather than curtail such freedom. They also provide recommendations on how to reduce the adverse impacts and enhance the positive impacts of the widespread use of digital technologies on freedom of expression in human rights-compliant ways.

title: Recommendation CM/Rec (2018)2 of the Committee of Ministers to member States on the roles and responsibilities of internet intermediaries
subtitle: Council of Europe, March 2018
description: In order to provide guidance to all relevant actors who are faced with the complex task of protecting and respecting human rights in the digital environment, this document establishes a list of recommendations to CoE member States, encouraging them to ensure that internet intermediaries fulfil their responsibilities to respect human rights in line with the recognized international standards.

title: IGF 2024 - Workshop on Leveraging Technology for Healthy Online Information Spaces - Outcome Report
subtitle: Office of the Representative on Freedom of the Media, December 2024
description: The Office of the Representative on Freedom of the Media organized a panel discussion at the 19th Internet Governance Forum (IGF) on 'Leveraging Technology for Healthy Online Information Spaces'. This session aimed at engaging discussions on the main challenges posed by Big Tech in the information landscape and how to address them. This short outcome report summarises the main takeaways and the main action points discussed by the panelists.

image: data/resources/140 - Joint Declaration on AI, FoE and Media Freedom.png
title: Joint Declaration on AI, Freedom of Expression and Media Freedom
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, UN Special Rapporteur on the Promotion and Protection of the Right to Freedom of Opinion and Expression, OAS Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression, and ACHPR Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression and Access to Information in Africa, October 2025
description: Joint Declaration on the challenges posed by AI to freedom of expression, media freedom and the overall information ecosystem by the special mandate holders on freedom of expression of the United Nations, the OSCE, the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights, and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. It provides principles and recommendations to different stakeholder groups.
href: Joint Declaration on AI, Freedom of Expression and Media Freedom | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: Policy Manual on Safeguarding Media Freedom in the Age of Big Tech Platforms and AI
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, October 2025
description: The Policy Manual presents a comprehensive analysis of existing policy approaches to media visibility, viability and vigilance (journalists' safety). Developed through in-depth research and several expert roundtables, interviews, and broad consultations, it consolidates the expertise of more than 150 leadings scholars and practitioners in media freedom, technology, and human rights across the OSCE region and beyond. The Policy Manual is designed to support states in ensuring the availability and accessibility of public interest journalism and reliable information, and provides concrete recommendations grounded in international human rights standards, OSCE commitments, and lessons learned from existing policy initiatives.
href: Safeguarding Media Freedom in the Age of Big Tech Platforms and AI | OSCE Projects

image: data/resources/142 - Illustration report on journalists in exile.png
title: Enhancing Protection of Journalists under Severe Political Pressure
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, September 2025
description: In an increasingly hostile environment for independent journalism, journalists under severe political pressure, particularly those in exile, represent the most vulnerable segment of the media landscape. This outcome report integrates testimonies, recommendations, and key findings from OSCE research as well as insights from other intergovernmental mandates and civil society organizations to better protect journalists in exile.
href: Outcome Report "Enhancing Protection of Journalists under Severe Political Pressure" | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

image: data/resources/143 - Joint statement on AI and FoE.png
title: Joint Statement on Artificial Intelligence and Freedom of Expression
subtitle: Office of OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, UN Special Rapporteur on the Promotion and Protection of the Right to Freedom of Opinion and Expression, OAS Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression, and ACHPR Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression and Access to Information in Africa, May 2025
description: Joint Statement on the challenges posed by AI to freedom of expression, media freedom and the overall information ecosystem by the special mandate holders on freedom of expression of the United Nations, the OSCE, the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights, and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights to mark World Press Freedom Day 2025. This statement resulted in the Joint Declaration on AI and Freedom of Expression and Media Freedom launched in October 2025.
href: Joint statement on Artificial Intelligence and Freedom of Expression | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: Public Value International #7 - "Defending Media Freedom Amid Evolving Threats", Interview of Jan Braathu, OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media
subtitle: ORF Public Value, October 2025
description: The number 7 of Public Value International published by the Austrian Broadcasting Corporation (ORF) focuses on populism and public service media, and includes an interview of Jan Braathu, OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media. The interview focuses in particular on defending media freedom amid evolving threats.

title: Think Again: Freedom of Thought in the Age of Artificial Intelligence - Policy Brief
subtitle: OSCE Office of Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, October 2025
description: This policy brief examines the implications for freedom of thought of the new information ecosystem, as well as the potential impacts of AI-based neurotechnologies, which raise fundamental questions about the inviolability of individual mental autonomy. The policy brief also outlines recommendations for states to consider in upholding freedom of thought in the digital age.
href: Think Again: Freedom of Thought in the Age of Artificial Intelligence | OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights

title: Guidance Note on the Implications of Generative AI for Freedom of Expression
subtitle: Council of Europe Steering Committee on Media and Information Society, December 2025
description: Generative AI presents growing risks for freedom of expression and democratic processes, including with regards to the fragmentation of the information space through hyper-personalised experiences, and the lack of transparency, accuracy, reliability and the potential for bias and manipulation of AI-generated content. The Guidance Note addresses these issues looking into specific impact on the right to freedom of expression, enshrined in Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights. It builds on insights, knowledge and experiences of a wide range of actors that have contributed to its elaboration.
href: New Guidance Note on Generative AI Implications for Freedom of Expression - Freedom of Expression

title: Ethical Use of Generative Artificial Intelligence in the Context of Preventing and Countering Violent Extremism and Radicalization that Lead to Terrorism - OSCE Policy Brief
subtitle: OSCE, December 2025
description: This policy brief is intended to provide guidance on the human rights-compliant use of generative AI for policymakers and practitioners in preventing and countering violent extremism and radicalization that lead to terrorism (P/CVERLT) - including government authorities and civil society actors.
href: Ethical Use of Generative Artificial Intelligence in the Context of Preventing and Countering Violent Extremism and Radicalization that Lead to Terrorism | OSCE Transnational Threats Department

title: OSCE Winter School on Youth perspectives on AI use and human rights - Workshop on AI and Freedom of Expression: Risks, Rights and Regulations, Outcome Report
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, December 2025
description: The Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media organized a session on 'AI and Freedom of Expression: Risks, Rights, and Regulations' during the OSCE Winter School on youth perspectives on AI use and human rights oranized by the Office of the OSCE Secretary General at the Geneva Centre for Security Policy. This session aimed to actively engage with young experts on key opportunities and challenges posed by AI with regard to access to information, freedom of expression and media freedom.
href: Outcome report – 2025 OSCE Winter School on “Risks and Opportunities of AI” | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: OSCE RFoM Conference on Healthy Online Information Spaces: From Policy Guidance to Pathways Forward, Final Report
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, January 2026
description: On 22 October 2025, the Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media organized the high-level conference "Healthy Online Information Spaces: From Policy Guidance to Pathways Forward" at Hofburg in Vienna. This final report presents an overview of the conference, including the launch of the Policy Manual on "Safeguarding Media Freedom in the Age of Big Tech Platforms and AI", and the interactive workshops and participatory sessions with key take-aways and recommendations for the RFoM and OSCE participating States.
href: Conference Report | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: Internet Governance Forum 2025, Session on Information Integrity Through Journalism and Alternative Platforms - Outcome Report
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, July 2025
description: This brief outcome report presents the main take-aways of a workshop jointly held by the OSCE RFoM, International Media Support, NIC Brazil, and Deutsche Welle Akademie at the 20th Annual Meeting of the Internet Governance Forum in Lillestrom, Norway, on 24 June 2025. The session focused on information integrity through journalism and alternative platforms. It aimed at exploring concrete solutions for supporting information integrity through quality journalism, while addressing the challenges and dominance of big tech companies in the online information ecosystem, and exploring alternative platforms and public interest technologies.
href: Outcome report – 2025 Internet Governance Forum session on “Information integrity through journalism and alternative platforms” | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: OSCE Supplementary Human Dimension Meeting - Side Event on "Support of Suppression: The Complex Role of Big Tech in Conflict Reporting" - Outcome Report
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, March 2025
description: This report presents the main take-aways of a side event hosted by the Office of the OSCE RFoM together with the freedom of expression organization ARTICLE 19 in the margins of the Supplementary Human Dimension Meeting (SHDM) organized in Vienna on 17 and 18 March 2025 by the Finnish OSCE Chairpersonship. The session's topic was "Support or Suppression: The Complex Role of Big Tech in Conflict Reporting", and focused on the complex relationship between Big Tech and journalists, how this complexity manifests in challenging contexts for media freedom, and how it specifically affects conflict reporting and documenting human rights violations and potential war crimes.
href: Outcome report – SHDM side event on “Support or suppression: the complex role of Big Tech in conflict reporting” | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: 10th RFoM Regional South East Europe Media Conference, Plenary session on "Rethinking the Economics of Public Interest Journalism in the Era of Big Tech and AI" - Outcome Report
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, and the Forum on Information and Democracy, May 2025
description: On 29 and 30 May 2025, the Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media organized in Sarajevo its 10th edition of the South East Europe Media Conference under the theme "Actioning Media Visibility for Informed, Resilient Societies". The Office's project on Healthy Online Information Spaces organized a plenary session on "Rethinking the economics of public interest journalism in the era of Big Tech and AI". The session explored the economic realities of independent quality journalism amidst the increasing dependency in Big Tech, the rise of generative AI, declining advertising revenue and diminishing pubic trust. This outcome report presents the main take-aways of the panel discussion.
href: Summary report - 10th regional South East Europe Media Conference plenary session 3 “Rethinking the economics of public interest journalism in the era of Big Tech and AI” | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: RightsCon 2025 - Workshop on "Information Integrity and Integrity of Information Spaces: States' Role in Ensuring a Healthy Information Ecosystem"
subtitle: Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, February 2025
description: The Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media held a workshop on information integrity, integrity of information spaces, and the role of states in ensuring a healthy information ecosystem at RightsCon 2025, a global conference on human rights in the digital age. The session had a specific focus on elections, risks of information manipulation and disinformation. This outcome report summarises the main take-aways of the panel discussions, and presents short-, mid-, and long-term solutions developed during the workshop.
href: Outcome report – 2025 RightsCon workshop on “Information integrity and integrity of information spaces” | OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media

title: Who Sets the Rules? Big Tech, AI and the Future of Media Freedom
subtitle: RNW Media and the Office of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media, November 2025
description: In this podcast episod of Media Actually powered by RNW Media on Big Tech, AI and the future of me dia freedom, Julia Haas, Advisor of the OSCE Representative on Freedom of the Media and manager of the project on Healthy Online Information Spaces, presents the Policy Manual on Safeguarding Media Freedom in the Age of Big Tech Platforms and AI, and explores the challenges and opportunities of protecting independent media in a rapidly evolving digital world.
href: Who Sets the Rules? Big Tech, AI and the Future of Media Freedom - Media Actually | Podcast on Spotify
